results.title: 20 years @ Metro
results.brief_description:
From U-Matic Video and offline editing to digital media production and training this video tracks the history of community access to program making in Sydney. It includes interviews and footage of filmmakers Tom Zubrycki, David Caesar and Vincent Sheehan, broadcasters Steven Wall and Chris Winter and Filmink editor Dov Kornits who talk about starting out in video at Metro. It features early clips of Andrew Denton and Nicole Kidman and award winning films by indigenous filmmakers and young people from Metro’s youth access unit Channel Free.
Metro Screen began as the Paddington Video Access Centre in 1974, it incorporated as Metro Television Ltd in 1981 and organised the community television trials and was a key organisational player in he establishment of community television services. It became Metro Screen Ltd in 1998 and moved into digital video and interactive multimedia production and became a Registered Training Organisation.
Metro’s archive collection of community and independent programs represents over 27 years of documentaries, dramas and experimental videos. Communities who have not been represented in mainstream media - Aboriginals, gays and lesbians, young people and women present their communities, their issues and themselves.
The programs are products of exhaustive, laborious and triumphant collaborations between various individuals and community groups working within the spirit of a truly democratic and representative media.
In 2001 to celebrate 20 years at Metro, Metro Screen produced this 25 minute documentary using footage from the archive collection.
The next 20 years at Metro will build on the strengths of the past and continue to provide access and innovation in independent screen production and training top a wider regional and Western Sydney market through mobile and online services.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 7 [The Big issue. International Women's day]
results.creator_credit: Northern Access TV, Michael Costello and David McLauchlan
results.brief_description: Et cetera “The Big Issue and International Woman’s Day” is an episode of the general interest magazine program “Et Cetera”. It contains two topics - the first is about the alternative magazine sold on the streets by homeless and unemployed people “The Big Issue”. The second is a look at the celebration of International Woman’s Day, which featrued a rally and march down Swanston Street in Melbourne.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 6 [Joe Felber Multimedia Installation]
results.creator_credit: Northern Access TV, Michael Costello and David McLauchlan
results.brief_description: Presented by David McLauchlan outside the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art, Melbourne. David interviews multimedia artist Joe Felber and dancer/choreographer Lucy Guerin about their collaborative installation with composer Elliott Gyger entitled “25 songs on 25 lines of 25 words on Art Statement for seven voices and dance” based on Ad Reinhardt’s Black Painting and Art Statement. Following the interviews, there is a presentation of Joe Felber’s 7 minute video on the multimedia performance “25 songs on 25 lines…and dance”.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 3 [1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival]
results.creator_credit: Northern Access TV, Michael Costello and David McLauchlan
results.brief_description:
Documents the 1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival Parade and the Fringe Furniture Exhibition, including interviews with Virginia Hyam, Fringe Director, and Axel, Fringe Furniture Co-ordinator. The Melbourne Fringe Festival has become an institution since its inception in 1982 when a small group of independent artists gathered together to create a platform to present new and independent art to the community. From those early beginnings the Melbourne-based festival now attracts interstate and international guests and covers a wide variety of arts
performances including outdoor events such as the Annual Parade in Brunswick Street, Fitzroy, the Annual Waiter’s Race, street-theatre and live bands and indoor events including comedy and cabaret, music and theatre. The Fringe Furniture Exhibition allows for young students
and designers an opportunity to show-off their creative ability and caters for non-mainstream pieces. Crazy, outrageous, quirky and even occasionally practical, the Exhibition contains an amazing selection of eclectic pieces as witnessed in this documentary program.
Reporters: Melissa Iaria and Phillip Taylor.

results.title: Victoria University Student Collection 2001
results.brief_description:
CD ROM work provided by Victoria University of exemplary work produced by students in their multimedia courses.

This interactive CD Rom and website documentary explores the life and music of virtuoso guitarist Slava Grigoryan.

The website and CD ROM hybrid allows for regular updates and particularly suited to the work as the guitarist travels frequently and can list concert and publication updates.

results.title: Within these walls
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: [Untitled]
results.brief_description:
“Untitled” is an interactive CD ROM that explores the changing view outside the window of its main character.

The use of black and white, and its simple graphic design add to the poignancy and impact of this innovative work.

“Untitled” presents a brooding, dark Beckett-like world of isolation and alienation. The characters appear disconnected from each other and dislocated from the world presented in the CD ROM.

results.title: Self construct
results.brief_description:
“Self Construct” explores the personal feelings of a young woman grappling with notions of self identity. The work explores complex ideas of exteranl /internal constructions of “self”. She asks the question - Where does ones identity come from?

Fontaine uses a cut up graphic style to to reflect her sense of dislocation and alienation from others.

Perceptions of memory and thought, interpretation and meaning, are all ideas explored in this innovative and thoughtful work.

“Self Construct” was awarded The Managesoft Award for “Best Final Year Interactive Project ” in the Victoria University BA multimedia course in 2001.

“Self Construct” is also a finalist in the Mayne Award for Multimedia Adelaide Festival Awards for Literature.
